Award.AwardTitle: CRII: SaTC: Energy Efficient Participatory Data Collection Schemes and Context-Aware Incentives for Trustworthy Crowdsensing via Mobile Social Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a crowdsensing system, energy efficient data collection is a primary concern for mobile sensing service providers (i.e., mobile users offering sensing as a service via built-in sensors on their mobile devices) in order to maximize battery life whereas trustworthiness is a primary concern for the end users. The proposed research will simultaneously address energy-efficient data collection and context-aware incentives to both minimize power consumption and maximize data trustworthiness. Furthermore, this research will propose new user-driven crowdsensing business models where smart phone users compete with each other for compensation based on the usefulness and trustworthiness of their sensing data. The ultimate societal impacts of the research are new crowdsensing applications in the areas of public safety, disaster management and community engagement that will be enabled by improved energy-efficient data collection, increased crowdsending trustworthiness through context aware sensing, and new crowdsensing business models that will incentivize more users to offer their mobile device built-in sensors as a service.

The proposed research will extend the ongoing efforts on trustworthy crowdsensing to address energy efficient data collection and new context-aware user incentive strategies to improve data trustworthiness. In order to address energy efficient data collection, coalitional game theory-based algorithms will be proposed while trustworthiness of the aggregated system will be addressed by defining new trustworthiness functions and context analysis of mobile social networks of the sensing data providers. These methodologies will be validated through comparison to benchmark optimization models. Statistical and collaborative trust scores will be used to introduce new trustworthiness and reputation functions for sensing service providers. The new trustworthiness and reputation functions will mitigate the impact of adversaries including the Sybils who aim at misinformation and manipulation. An emphasis will be placed on compatibility with emerging mobile social network (MSN) models and their associated spatio-temporal context analyses. The research will be completed by building a framework which combines the merits of energy efficient data collection and context-aware user incentives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project has investigated the feasibility of applying game theoretic solutions in mobile crowd-sensing systems to incentivize truthful user participation. Furthermore, the project has developed energy efficient data acquisition models against de-incentivization of smartphone users because of battery drain concerns. 

The research project proposed a new decentralized trustworthiness assessment scheme by incorporating Sybil detection in social networks into a mobile crowd-sensing setting in the presence of adversaries. As decentralized Sybil detection is primarily based on aggregated recommendation, potential community bias has also been addressed by combining statistical reputation assessment of participants and a community recommendation system. 

Game theoretic approaches have been introduced as an extension to the decentralized Sybil detection approaches. This aimed to bridge auction and game theories for effective incentivization. A repetitive subgame and a coalitional game have been proposed to improve participation of trustworthy users in mobile crowd-sensing. One of the important findings of the research was the presentation of the impact of repetitive subgames (and its integration with gamification) on improved utility for participants and platforms, as well as the trustworthiness and usefulness of the crowd-sensed data. 

In the last year, the project also investigated the possibility of software-defined (selective) sensing in mobile crowd-sensing systems in terms of data trustworthiness and energy efficiency of mobile devices. The community selectiveness of sensing data providers is basically turning off the corresponding sensors in the mobile devices while having the rest of the sensor array remain on. Communities are formed by the participants that are assigned common sensing tasks. The research reported that in order for dependable community selectiveness to introduce remarkable energy savings without compromising platform and/or user utilities, further investigations are required.

The research also introduced the "sociability-aware" recruitment concept to ensure energy efficiency in mobile devices. Sociability denotes the behavioral context on social networking platforms, which is also used to verify the participants on the devices through various machine learning algorithms. Sociability of users is a function of the participants' data consumption and the time they spend on mobile social network applications. The proposed framework to verify the users on mobile devices achieved reasonably high authenticity without the need of any human intervention. Thus, one of the remarkable outcomes of the research is the empowering machine learning to improve the veracity of crowd-sensed data by identifying any misuse attempt on participating devices (i.e. spoofed identities or participants who are not supposed to be in possession of admitted mobile smart devices). Once users are verified on mobile devices, their sociability signatures are used as indicators of willingness to participate in the campaigns and more importantly an indicator of activity on mobile phones. Therefore, user incentives are coupled with sociability-awareness to minimize the energy consumption overhead on the devices. Sociability-aware recruitment awareness can ensure to save significant amount of the battery lifetime when compared to the energy-unaware recruitment of users by rewarding incentives.

Research results have been disseminated through established conferences and journals of respected publishers / organizations. Throughout the lifetime of this award, two Ph.D theses, one Master's thesis, and an Honor's thesis have been completed. One of the two Ph.D theses was completed by a female student. The graduate students who have been trainees in this project have graduated with excellent publication records not only in terms of quantity but also in terms of quality and impact as these works have been being cited by many researchers in this field. Moreover, the research has also helped the PI update the curriculum of a graduate course (Cloud Systems and Networks) at Clarkson University in 2015 and 2016 as research findings were presented to the graduate students in ECE and CS programs. Last but not least, the project also offered training opportunities to undergraduate students as well. A visual tool was developed by a set of undergraduate students in Software Design for Visual Environments (taught by the PI) to simulate distributed estimation on a sensor network platform. The tool can be used in undergraduate digital signal processing and communications classes to teach students the basic concepts of statistical signal processing.
